::: {#intro-page .content-page .active} ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}

SOURCEBOOK

Understand your community's housing needs.

``` ::: ::: **Sourcebook** is HousingForward Virginia's online compendium of housing data. It collects, summarizes, and presents dozens of different data points to help users understand housing trends in their communities to advocate for and implement better housing solutions. Housing and housing-related data is spread across multiple sources and can be time-consuming to clean up, analyze, and visualize. Sourcebook brings together the most important data points in one place to make that work simpler for you. Sourcebook is an evolving and user-focused resource. We encourage you to contact us if there are particular features you would like to see, or data points that would be most helpful to your work. ## Getting Started Use the sidebar to navigate through different housing data topics: - **Demographics:** Population, age, race and ethnicity data - **Economics:** Income, poverty, and employment trends - **Inventory:** Housing stock, production, and characteristics - **Homeownership & Rental:** Market trends and affordability - **Affordability:** Cost burden and housing gaps - **Instability:** Homelessness data - **Economic Impact Calculators:** Tools to estimate job and economic growth *Select your geographic area at the top of the sidebar, then explore the data topics that interest you most.* ::: ::: {#demographics-total-population .content-page} # Total Population The dashboards on this page include data on total population counts and components of population change. These trends help reveal how much, and for what reasons, population levels may be increasing or decreasing over time. ## Total population The 2020 Census was greatly impacted by the pandemic, as well as the use of differential privacy. The Demographics Research Group at the University of Virginia's Weldon Cooper Center advises data users to treat 2020 Census numbers with caution. But overall, they find that 2020 Census data "tends to be more reliable for larger areas and populations whereas in Virginia's smaller localities, data errors and distortions are much more common." This dashboard shows annual population counts and percent changes. Data for 2010 and 2020 are from those years' Decennial Census counts; all other years use estimates from the Census Bureau's Population Estimates Program (PEP). Data is available at the state, CBSA, and locality level. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Total population change This dashboard shows annual population changes as both raw numbers and percentages, helping to understand growth patterns and demographic trends over time. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Components of population change This dashboard breaks down annual population changes by three different components: - Natural increases (births minus deaths), - Domestic migration (net moves from in/out of state), and - International migration (net moves from in/out of the country). Data is available at the state, CBSA, and locality level. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ## Additional resources - [U.S. Census Bureau](https://www.census.gov/) - [Virginia adds more than 600,000 people since 2010](#) - [UVA Weldon Cooper Center](https://demographics.coopercenter.org/) - [State population growth slows, with most new residents in Northern Virginia](#) - [Comparing 2020 Virginia population projections to the Census count](#) ### Data Sources #### Census Population Estimates Program (PEP) Annual estimates of total population released by the U.S. Census Bureau. Available at locality level from 2010 to 2024. Estimates by age, race, and ethnicity also available, along with components of population change. #### 2020 Decennial Census Official population counts from the 2020 Census, used as baseline data for population estimates. ::: ::: {#inventory-housing-type .content-page} # Housing Type by Tenure The dashboards on this page break down housing stock by the number of homes within each building. For example, a 1-unit residential building is a single-family home, while a 5-unit residential building is a small apartment complex. These data are helpful in understanding the makeup of a community's housing supply, overall density, and construction trends. ## Housing type by tenure This dashboard shows the current supply of occupied housing units among owners, renters, and all households, broken down by number of homes within each building. All homes are classified into one of the following six categories: - **Single-family (detached)** are homes with one living unit that does not share any walls with another home. - **Single-family (attached)** are homes with one living unit that shares at least one wall with another home. - **Small-scale multifamily** are homes in buildings with 2 to 19 total units. This includes duplexes, triplexes, and other similar buildings of three stories or fewer. This typically includes low-rise and mid-rise apartments. - **Medium-scale multifamily** are homes in buildings with 20 to 49 total units. This typically includes low-rise and mid-rise apartments. - **Large-scale multifamily** are homes in buildings with 50 or more total units. This typically includes mid-rise and high-rise apartments. - **Mobile (manufactured) home** are factory-built homes that are fully built on a chassis. These homes are built to meet standards promulgated by the U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development (the "HUD Code") and are distinct from modular/prefabricated homes. Data is available at the state, CBSA, and locality level. **NOTE:** The American Community Survey also includes an 'Other' category for certain housing types. These homes include boats, recreational vehicles (RVs), vans, and all other units that do not fall into one of the above categories. We have omitted this category because the share of these 'Other' units is insignificant (less than one percent) across all geographies in Virginia. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Additional Resources [How Virginia communities are encouraging 'Missing Middle Housing'](#) - Planetizen ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey The American Community Survey is an ongoing survey program of the U.S. Census Bureau. The ACS collects information about the nation's social, economic, housing, and demographic characteristics on an annual basis. This information provides the most-up-to-date estimates between decennial censuses. This section uses data from one ACS table: **Table B25032:** Tenure by Units in Structure The most recent data used for this section are the 2018-2022 5-year estimates. These estimates average all survey responses across this period to increase sample sizes and reduce margins of error. The data contained in Sourcebook is intended for informational, educational and research uses. The information may not be used for commercial purposes or re-marketed. Any reproduction and distribution of this information must clearly identify HousingForward Virginia and Sourcebook as the provider of the information. ::: ::: {#demographics-race-ethnicity .content-page} # Race and Ethnicity Population by race and Hispanic or Latino heritage. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Population estimates by race and ethnicity from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#demographics-age .content-page} # Age Population data by age groups. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Age distribution data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#demographics-household-type .content-page} # Household Type Relationships of people living under the same roof. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Household composition data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#demographics-household-size .content-page} # Household Size Number of persons per household. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Household size distribution from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#economics-household-income .content-page} # Household Income Income by tenure, age, race and ethnicity. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Household income data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#economics-poverty .content-page} # Poverty Poverty rates by age, race and ethnicity. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Poverty status data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#economics-employment .content-page} # Employment Job levels, unemployment rates, and jobs-housing ratios. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Bureau of Labor Statistics Employment and unemployment data from federal and state labor statistics. ::: ::: {#inventory-housing-production .content-page} # Housing Production Building permits by structure type. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### U.S. Census Bureau Building Permits Survey New construction authorized by building permits. ::: ::: {#inventory-housing-age .content-page} # Housing Age Housing stock by tenure and year built. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Year structure built data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#inventory-housing-characteristics .content-page} # Housing Characteristics Physical characteristics of housing stock. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Housing unit characteristics from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#inventory-overcrowding .content-page} # Overcrowding Number of persons per room. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Occupancy characteristics from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#homeownership-rate .content-page} # Homeownership Rate Share of homeowners by age, race and ethnicity. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Housing tenure data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#homeownership-sales .content-page} # Home Sales For-sale prices and inventory trends. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Virginia Association of Realtors Home sales and pricing data from local real estate markets. ::: ::: {#homeownership-hpi .content-page} # House Price Index Historic-to-present Federal Housing Finance Agency HPI. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Federal Housing Finance Agency House Price Index data showing price changes over time. ::: ::: {#homeownership-mortgages .content-page} # Mortgages Loan originations and denials by race and ethnicity. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Home Mortgage Disclosure Act (HMDA) Mortgage lending data from the Consumer Financial Protection Bureau. ::: ::: {#rental-rent .content-page} # Rent Gross rent averages and spread. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Gross rent data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#rental-vacancy .content-page} # Rental Vacancy Vacancy rates for rental properties. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Housing vacancy data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#rental-assisted .content-page} # Assisted Rentals Homes with dedicated public subsidies. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### HUD and Virginia Housing Subsidized housing data from federal and state agencies. ::: ::: {#affordability-cost-burden .content-page} # Housing Cost Burden Cost burden by income, race and ethnicity. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### American Community Survey Housing cost burden data from the U.S. Census Bureau. ::: ::: {#affordability-gap .content-page} # Rental Housing Gap Affordability of current supply by income. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### National Low Income Housing Coalition Housing affordability gap analysis. ::: ::: {#affordability-ami .content-page} # HUD AMI Limits Income limits used by affordable housing programs. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Area Median Income limits for affordable housing programs. ::: ::: {#instability-homelessness .content-page} # Homelessness Point-in-Time homelessness for Continuum of Care regions. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### U.S. Department of Housing and Urban Development Point-in-Time count data from Continuum of Care regions. ::: ::: {#calculators-new-construction .content-page} # New Construction Calculator Estimate job and economic growth from new construction. The Virginia Center for Housing Research developed these calculators to estimate the economic impact of housing activity on local economies. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Virginia Center for Housing Research Economic impact methodology based on regional economic modeling. ::: ::: {#calculators-renovation .content-page} # Renovation Calculator Estimate job and economic growth from major rehab projects. The Virginia Center for Housing Research developed these calculators to estimate the economic impact of housing activity on local economies. ::: {.cell} ::: {.cell-output-display} ```{=html}
``` ::: ::: ### Data Sources #### Virginia Center for Housing Research Economic impact methodology for renovation and rehabilitation projects. :::
